Report and Recommendation of the President  
to the Board of Directors
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 33209 
March 2014 
 
 
 
Proposed Loan for Additional Financing 
Nepal: Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture 
Sector Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public prior to Board consideration in accordance with 
ADB’s Public Communications Policy 2011. Subject to any revisions required following Board 
consideration, this document is deemed final.

NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Nepal ends on 15 July. “FY” before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2013 ends on 15 July 2013.  
 
(ii) In this report, “$” refers to US dollars.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to Nepal for the additional financing of the Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture Sector 
Project.1 
 
2.  The additional financing is for the current project, which is performing well. The project 
will expand project outputs and activities to additional areas. It has a high degree of readiness in 
design, implementation, and safeguards. Its design and implementation arrangements have 
been reviewed during loan processing, and adjustments have been made as necessary. The 
project remains technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound. It supports the 
government’s development objectives and is accorded top priority by the government.  
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
A.  Rationale 
3.  Agriculture  is  Nepal’s  primary  economic  sector;  about  80%  of  the  population  is 
dependent on it. Since most of the poor reside in rural areas, Nepal’s poverty reduction strategy 
recognizes that agricultural growth is essential for attaining broad-based economic growth and 
improving  livelihoods.  Agriculture  is  largely  based  on  low-value  crops  and  subsistence 
production, with only about 17% of output traded in markets. Because agriculture growth has 
been erratic, determined to a large extent by climatic factors, food production remains unstable.2 
Irrigation is an essential input to improve agriculture productivity. Nepal’s recently completed 
Agriculture Development Strategy recognizes the importance of expanding the irrigated areas in 
an equitable and viable manner, and improving irrigation efficiency and management.3 The new 
Irrigation Policy (2013) also promotes improved agency- and farmer-managed irrigation systems 
to improve water efficiency and year-round irrigation.   
4.  The expansion of irrigation from the mid-1970s provided an enabling environment for the 
use of new high-yielding varieties and fertilizer. Irrigation expansion has also imparted a greater 
degree of stability to farm production. Of the 2.64 million hectares (ha) of cultivable land in 
Nepal, 1.77 million ha is irrigable and about 1.33 million ha has access to irrigation. Investments 
are required to rehabilitate and improve existing irrigation systems and strengthen water users 
associations  (WUAs)  to  operate  and  maintain  them  efficiently.  Improved  agricultural 
technologies, availability of inputs, and the provision of supplementary irrigation during the 
monsoon season and full irrigation in the dry season can increase rice yields from about 3 tons 
per ha per year to as high as 10–12 tons per ha per year.4 Dependable irrigation also provides 
farmers with an incentive to diversify from low-value cereal crops to high-value crops such as 
fruits and vegetables, and increase their incomes and nutrition at the same time.   
                                                
1  Asian Development Bank (ADB). 2004. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: 
Proposed Loan to Nepal for the Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture Sector Project. Manila. The design and 
monitoring framework of the overall project is in Appendix 1 and has been updated to conform with current ADB 
standards. 
2  Agricultural production depends on a 4-month monsoon, when 75% of annual rains fall. Climate variability and 
change in Nepal is projected to exacerbate existing threats to food, water, and livelihood security through 
alterations in the quantity and timing of precipitation and runoff, more atmospheric water vapor and evaporation, 
and progressive loss of glacier and snowpack storage in basin headwaters.  
3  ADB. 2013. Preparation of the Agricultural Development Strategy: Final Report. Consultant’s report. Kathmandu 
(TA 7762-NEP). 
4  ADB.  2012.  Preparation  of  the  Agricultural  Development  Strategy:  Assessment  Report.  Consultant’s  report. 
Kathmandu (TA 7762-NEP).

2 
5.  The government has a mature program of assisting farmer-managed irrigation systems 
(FMIS) to upgrade their primary infrastructure. The total number of FMIS is estimated at over 
15,000, and about 3,000 have received some form of support from the government and various 
development  partners.  The  government  estimates  that  a  large  number  of  FMIS,  with  a 
combined command area of about 250,000 ha, never received assistance. Additional financing 
for the current project will allow rehabilitation and expansion efforts to reach a larger number of 
FMIS.  
6.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the current project on 17 November 2004 
and it became effective on 13 January 2006. It will close on 30 September 2014. The current 
project had the overall goal of promoting inclusive economic growth while reducing poverty in 
rural areas. Its specific objective is to improve the agriculture productivity and sustainability of 
existing medium-sized FMIS5 and thereby enhance the livelihoods of poor men and women, 
including ethnic minorities and  Dalit. To achieve this objective, the project  is rehabilitating 
111 FMIS,  with  strengthened  WUAs  in  the  central  and  eastern  development  regions.  The 
government  also  provides  agricultural  extension  and  livelihood  enhancement  services  in 
subproject areas. 
7.  Project performance was assessed during preparation of the additional financing.6 Some 
of the targets for the current project were revised at midterm because of cost escalations. The 
current project is likely to meet the revised targets. Upon completion of the current project in 
September 2014, the total irrigation command area improved is expected to be 15,677 ha 
(target 13,700 ha). The beneficiaries will total 178,285 (target 115,600). Although it is too early 
to  assess  achievement  of  agricultural  production  targets,  the  government’s  initial  findings 
indicate that the average cropping intensity in subproject areas has increased by 30% (target 
40%), and annual major crop production has increased by 42,000 tons (target 32,100 tons). The 
current  project  supported  the  reformulation  and  strengthening  of  WUAs,  and  nearly  80% 
farmers  enrolled  as  members,  on  average.  Beneficiary  contributions  totaled  4.5%  of 
construction costs (target 3.0%). Its gender targets have been met. Women’s representation in 
WUA executive committees was 30% (target 33%) and 48% in agriculture extension activities 
(target 35%).  
8.  The  quality  of  subproject  implementation  was  also  assessed.  Construction  works 
performed  by  both  contractors  and  WUAs  has  been  generally  satisfactory.  Construction 
supervision and timely supervision by the Department of Irrigation (DOI) will be improved during 
the  project  in  light  of  lessons  learned  from  the  current  project.7 Social  and  institutional 
development focused on strengthening WUAs to manage their irrigation systems independently. 
The current project trained lead farmers in preparing operation and maintenance (O&M) plans, 
but more hands-on technical assistance is required through additional financing to ensure these 
plans are implemented. A new target of having an O&M and financing mechanism established 
for each WUA has been set.  
9.  Once the irrigation infrastructure is approved, equitable and adequate water distribution 
systems should be established to optimize agricultural productivity. The current project did not 
allocate resources or expertise to guide WUAs in constructing water courses to bring water to 
farm fields or in agreeing on water distribution arrangements to meet agricultural goals. The 
                                                
5  Irrigation schemes covering 25–500 ha in the hills and 200–2,000 ha in the Terai (the southern plains) are defined 
as medium-sized. 
6  Summary of Project Performance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
7  Actions to improve construction management have been agreed with the government and delineated in the Project 
Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

3 
additional  financing  project  has  significantly  enhanced  procedures  and  implementation 
arrangements for building WUA capacity in integrated crop and water management (ICWM). 
10.  As of 28 February 2014, overall physical progress was estimated at 96% against the 
elapsed loan period of 94%. The cumulative contract award was $16.13 million (89.6%) and 
disbursement  was  $15.25  million  (84.7%).  Of  the  $7  million  OPEC  Fund  for  International 
Development  (OFID)  loan,  the  cumulative  contract  award  is  $5.88  million  (84%)  and 
disbursement was $4.33 million (61.85%). The current project is expected to complete the 
remaining works by the loan closing date of 30 September 2014. Due to construction bids 
substantially below engineering cost estimates and significant currency fluctuation, $2 million of 
the loan was cancelled in November 2013. Compliance with loan covenants and environmental 
and social safeguards is satisfactory. The eligibility requirements for additional financing have 
been met.  
B.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  Additional financing will continue to focus on rehabilitating and extending the irrigation 
coverage of farmer-managed irrigation systems in the central and eastern development regions. 
It will also support the rehabilitation of select irrigation systems that are currently receiving direct 
government support; the management will be transferred to WUAs after system development 
and WUA strengthening. The project will be implemented through about 70 community-based 
subprojects. 
 
12.  The expected impact will be increased national food security. The expected outcome is 
that participating farmers increase agricultural production. Productivity will be measured through 
(i) yields of major crops increased by at least 30% in subproject areas, and (ii) cropping intensity 
in irrigated areas increased by at least 30%.  
 
C.  Outputs 
13.  To  achieve  its  expected  outcome, the  project  will  have  four  outputs:  (i)  farmers  in 
subproject  areas  have  improved  irrigation  infrastructure;  (ii)  WUAs  independently  manage 
irrigation systems in a socially inclusive and equitable manner; (iii) farmers adopt improved 
agricultural  practices;  and  (iv)  national  institutions  are  strengthened  for  effective  irrigation 
service delivery.    
 
14.  Improved irrigation infrastructure. The project will support the participatory planning, 
detailed design, and construction of infrastructure such as diversion structures, cross-drainage 
works, improved and extended canal systems, and flood protection facilities. All subproject 
infrastructure design will be done in close consultation with WUAs. The project will also support 
the construction of tertiary water courses that bring the water to farm fields. WUAs will provide 
beneficiary contribution in labor and/or cash for subproject infrastructure costs, consistent with 
the government’s Irrigation Policy (2013). 
 
15.  Irrigation  systems  management. The  project  will  empower WUAs  to  manage  the 
rehabilitation  of  the  infrastructure,  operate  and  maintain  their  systems  without  government 
support, and distribute the water equitably and adequately throughout the command area. WUA 
executive committees will be reconstituted, as necessary, to ensure equal representation of the 
head, middle, and tail of the canal system, and to empower women and other disadvantaged 
farmers  to  lead  in  system  management.  WUAs  in  subprojects  that  are  currently  agency-
managed will develop plans to manage their systems without government support.

4 
16.  Improved  agricultural  practices.  Agricultural  practices  in  subproject  areas  are 
predominantly conventional. Farmers are using their own seed stock repeatedly for 5–10 years, 
resulting in lost production potential. Chemical fertilizer use is unbalanced, and farmers are not 
well trained in making organic fertilizers. Inefficient plot-to-plot flooding irrigation is regularly 
practiced rather than constructing field channels. The project will provide agricultural extension 
services to subproject areas to build the capacity of farmers in sustainable agricultural systems.  
 
17.  Institutional strengthening and project management. The project has supported the 
preparation of policies for irrigation and integrated water resources management, a national 
water plan, improved procedures for project management, revised engineering manuals, and 
institutional strategy and action plans. The next phase of policy and institutional reforms will be 
supported  through  additional  financing,  including  preparing  an  irrigation  act,  updating  the 
irrigation regulation, and preparing guidelines for management transfer and O&M. 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans  
 
18.  The project is estimated to cost $38.3 million (Table 1).

19.  The  government  has  requested  a  loan  in  various  currencies  equivalent  to 
SDR19,418,000 from ADB’s Special Funds resources to help finance the project. The loan will 
have a 32-year term, including a grace period of 8 years, an interest rate of 1.0% per annum 
during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter, and such other terms and conditions 
set  forth  in  the  draft  loan  agreement.  The  Government  of  Nepal  will  provide  $7.5  million 
equivalent. Beneficiaries will contribute to subproject costs through labor and cash equivalent to 
$0.8 million. The financing plan is in Table 2.

5

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  The Ministry of Irrigation will delegate the authority of project management to the DOI. 
The DOI will be the executing agency. It has already established a central project management 
office (CPMO) for the current project. The CPMO will be headed by a full-time project director.8 
In addition, it will include the following full-time staff: deputy project director, account officer, 
accountant,  and  supporting  staff  (administrative  assistant).  The  CPMO  is  responsible  for 
managing all aspects of project implementation.  
21.  The Department of Agriculture (DOA) is the implementing agency. The Directorate of 
Agriculture Extension will continue to lead the project implementation unit; its program director 
will be responsible for managing the DOA’s components under the project—the agricultural 
development component and agricultural aspects of the ICWM component.  
22.  Subproject preparation and implementation will be the responsibility of the irrigation 
development divisions and subdivisions and the district agriculture development offices. The 
regional  irrigation  and  agriculture  directorates  will  monitor  subproject  implementation  and 
ensure implementation progress and results.  
23.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 
the project administration manual.9

24.  The Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development (KFAED) has indicated its intention to 
provide a loan of about $17 million equivalent to the government to finance the construction of 
subprojects over and above those financed by ADB and the government. Activities supported by 
KFAED will be financed on a parallel basis, with ADB assuming no supervision or fiduciary 
obligations. OFID has also expressed interest to provide a loan of $30 million equivalent to the 
government to finance additional subprojects beyond those to be financed by ADB and KFAED. 
The  details  of  OFID’s  involvement  are  being  finalized.  Once  the  nature  of  cofinancing 
arrangement is finalized with OFID, if necessary, a separate approval of the Board will be 
sought. 
 
III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
A.  Technical  
25.  The  implementation  systems  and  procedures  for  subproject  preparation,  design, 
construction  supervision  and  quality  control,  and  post-construction  support  for  O&M  were 
reviewed during loan processing. Relatively simple methodologies and tools were introduced, 
using the latest technologies and internet, to achieve a higher and more consistent level of 
quality  in  project  preparation,  detailed  design,  and  monitoring  of  small-  and  medium-scale 
irrigation  schemes. This  has  included  (i)  the  introduction  of  global  positioning  system  and 
geographic  information  system-based  survey  and  mapping  methodologies;  (ii)  the  use  of 
available  digital  topographic  mapping;  (iii)  high  resolution  satellite  imagery;  and  (iv)  the

7 
development  and  introduction  of  templates  and  automated  procedures  for  project  design, 
including  online  data  processing  and  report  generation.  These  standardized  procedures 
significantly improved the quality of subproject preparation and, as all documents are now 
available online, review and quality control has also improved. The capacity of DOI field staff 
has  improved,  and  they  take  the  lead  on  infrastructure  planning,  design,  construction 
supervision, and O&M training. 
 
26.  The current project carried out very limited activities to support O&M, partly because of 
implementation  delays.  To  improve  long-term  sustainability,  the  project  includes  support 
activities for post-construction, including O&M training, on-farm level demonstrations, and ICWM 
training. Post-construction support will also be extended for one full year after completion of 
infrastructure rehabilitation. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial  
27.  Economic analysis was undertaken on a sample of both FMIS and agency-managed 
irrigation system (AMIS). The cultivated command area (CCA) of sample schemes is about 
50 ha in the hills, and 200 ha to 300 ha for the schemes located in the Terai.10 The AMIS 
scheme is larger, with a CCA of 450 ha. The number of households cultivating land in the FMIS 
schemes analyzed is 35 to 300 in the hills, and 170 to 350 in the Terai. In the AMIS scheme, the 
number of households is 850. The percentage of households cultivating less than 1 ha is 54% to 
92%, and those cultivating less than 0.5 ha is 41% to 54%. 
 
28.  Economic benefits will  derive from an increase in crop yields and diversification of 
cropping patterns toward higher value crops, resulting from improved irrigation delivery. Overall, 
an increase in the production of cereals of about 100 tons per year on FMIS schemes in the 
hills, and 480 tons per year on schemes in the Terai is expected. On the larger AMIS scheme 
analyzed, cereal production is expected to increase by almost 800 tons per year. Incremental 
production  of  vegetables  varies  significantly  across  schemes  but  is  expected  to  be                 
100–800 tons per year. Annual increases in the value of production across all schemes range 
from  NRs12  million  to  NRs76  million.  Economic  analysis  indicates  that  for  the  FMIS,  the 
economic internal rates of return range from 29.6% to 55.8%. The economic internal rates of 
return  of  the  AMIS  scheme  analyzed  is  35.5%.  Sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  scheme 
economic viability is not sensitive to adverse changes in benefits or costs or delays in the 
attainment  of  benefits.  The  project  is  also  financially  sustainable.  Farm  income  analysis 
indicates significant increases in farm incomes, suggesting that farm households will have the 
capacity  to  finance  the  increased  O&M  costs  associated  with  rehabilitated  irrigation 
infrastructure through their contributions to WUAs. 
 
C.  Governance 
29.  The project supports local governance, financial and administrative decentralization, and 
oversight of public development expenditure by deepening the transparency and accountability 
of public service delivery through local government units that select and manage their own 
subprojects,  and  by  building  the  capacity  of  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies for 
financial discipline, responsibility, transparency, and accountability. A financial management 
assessment of the DOI and DOA was conducted, and a risk assessment and risk management 
plan was prepared.11 The assessment concluded that the DOI’s and DOA’s capacity is sufficient 
                                                
10  The southern plains region. 
11  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

8 
to carry out the project with training and oversight from ADB. The project aims to support the 
post-conflict approach outlined in the country partnership strategy, 2010–2012 by identifying 
and managing potential conflict risks and opportunities.12 
30.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  DOI.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the project administration manual (footnote 9). 
D.  Poverty and Social 
31.  The  project  involves  rehabilitating  existing  irrigation  systems  that  serve  the  poor, 
disadvantaged and vulnerable farmers, and sharecroppers in the eastern and central regions of 
Nepal; and addresses the issues of hunger and undernutrition and improving access to agri-
technology and inputs through improved irrigation and crop diversification and intensification—
resulting in an increase in household income for a more food-secure future. Defined on the 
basis of food sufficiency, 30% of the proposed beneficiaries are $1.25-a-day poor.13 The project 
is based on demand-driven, participatory planning processes. A shift to irrigated agriculture and 
vegetable farming is expected to lift most of the poor above the poverty line. 
 
32.  The project is classified as having an effective gender mainstreaming theme. A gender 
equity and social inclusion plan has been made an integral part of the project design and is 
covered by one of the covenants.14 The current project’s adherence to the government policy—
requiring  at  least  33%  women’s  representation  in  all  registered  WUAs—has  gradually 
diminished opposition to women’s involvement in WUA committees. However, as women’s 
participation is deemed to be a token, this highlights the need for extra capacity building training 
for women WUA executive members to enable them to participate on a par with local elites and 
male counterparts. This project addresses such issues through leadership and technical training 
for WUA executive committee members, gender equity and social inclusion sensitization training 
for members of WUA executive committees, and training for leader farmers. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
33.  Environment. The project is classified category B for environment as it is unlikely that 
any  proposed  subprojects  will  lead  to  irreversible  damage.  Any  subproject  screened  as 
category A will not be financed. Potential impacts from climate change and natural disasters on 
the project and its proposed interventions have been screened.15 Rehabilitation of irrigation 
headworks and canals may result in a few negative impacts that can easily  be mitigated. 
Screening  for  environmental  impacts  will  be  conducted  on  each  subproject  and  initial 
environmental examinations prepared. The approved environmental assessment and review 
framework,  as  disclosed  on  the  ADB  website,  provides  guidance  on  categorization  and 
procedures  to  be  followed  during  implementation.16 Contracts  for  subprojects  that  require 
environmental assessments will be awarded only after approval of the initial environmental 
examinations and environmental management plans by ADB and the government (if required), 
                                                
12  ADB. 2009. Country Partnership Strategy: Nepal, 2010–2012. Manila; Nepal Post-Conflict Sensitive Approach: A 
Peace-Building Tool (Peace Filter) for Project Design and Implementation (accessible from the list of linked 
documents in Appendix 2). 
13 This is based on a qualitative assessment. 
14  Gender Action Plan: Gender Equity and Social Inclusion Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2). 
15  Climate Change: Project Adaptation Action Report (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
16 Environmental Assessment and Review Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
and will form part of the contract documents. A grievance redress committee will be established 
in  each  subproject  area  to  receive,  evaluate,  and  facilitate  resolution  of  affected  people’s 
concerns on environmental and social issues. 
34.  Involuntary resettlement. The project is categorized C for involuntary resettlement. It is 
designed  to  be  based  on  voluntary  donation  of  land,  on  demand,  from  the  poor  and 
marginalized farmers, sharecroppers, and leaseholders. A voluntary land donation due diligence 
framework17 has been prepared to help assess the involuntary resettlement safeguard status of 
a proposed subproject, and confirm that the selection criteria involving the voluntary donation of 
land have been met. Any subproject requiring involuntary land acquisition will be dropped. 
Irrigation improvement must be desired by a community. If any land acquisition is required for 
irrigation enhancement, community members will voluntarily donate small parcels of their land, 
and they will be considered primary beneficiaries of the enhanced irrigation facility. Procedures 
have been established to verify that the land is being provided voluntarily by those who stand to 
gain directly, and to verify that the subproject will cause no impoverishment. Land donation 
should not exceed 10% of a farmer’s agricultural landholding within the command area, or the 
WUA  must  provide  livelihood  restitution  measures.  The  land  donation  will  be  verified  by 
witnesses and documented. Grievance redress committees will address any grievances. The 
DOI has a long history of facilitating voluntary land donation, and the due diligence arrangement 
has been working well under the current project which was also categorized C. No grievances 
are outstanding. 
 
35.  Indigenous peoples. The project is categorized C for indigenous peoples. While the 
project expects to reach areas with high percentages of Janajatis (the indigenous peoples 
communities), the indigenous peoples safeguard requirements will not be triggered because the 
project does not directly or indirectly affect their dignity, human rights, livelihood systems, or 
culture or cultural properties. The project is demand-driven, based on voluntary donation of land 
and is for the benefit of the poor, disadvantaged and vulnerable farmers, sharecroppers, and 
leaseholders that include the indigenous peoples communities. A due diligence framework for 
indigenous peoples impact screening, with a checklist, has been prepared. Subproject selection 
criteria  will  exclude  proposals  that  involve  any  adverse  impact  on the  indigenous  peoples 
communities and that will not qualify as category C for the indigenous peoples safeguard.18  
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
36.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.19  
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures  
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Project implementation will be through two  The DOI will establish a computerized project 
government agencies and 65 units. They have  accounting system. A computer-based financial 
limited understanding of ADB’s financial  information system with necessary hardware and 
management guidelines and will incur a large  internet access will be established at district level 
volume of small transactions. This could result in  implementing entities. A financial management 
inadequate financial reporting.  consultant will provide regular financial management 
training for accounting staff in all project implementing 
entities, in particular in project budgeting, reporting 
                                                
17  Voluntary Land Donation Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
18  Indigenous Peoples Screening Framework (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
19  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

10 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
requirements, and ADB’s disbursement procedures. 
Malfeasance could occur in bidding for civil  The DOI will closely supervise procurement to 
works contracts. Potential risks include the  minimize such risks, and ADB will conduct prior review 
imposition of informal conditions, illicit payments  of bid evaluations before contract awarding. A 
for officials, bid rigging, collusion and fraud, and  procurement specialist will conduct annual audits to 
deviations from original bid documents.  check for irregularities in the bidding and awarding of 
contracts, and report findings to the DOI and ADB for 
follow-up. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as 
amended to date) will be disseminated to all project 
staff and stakeholders. Upon the recommendation of 
the CPMO, the public procurement monitoring office 
will blacklist contractors and suppliers proven to be 
involved in corrupt activities. The chief district officer, 
who has responsibility for anticorruption, will receive 
and act upon genuine complaints. 
Government staff could provide insufficient  The DOI has agreed on actions for improving contract 
oversight and monitoring of performance of civil  management. Performance conditions have been 
works contractors.  strengthened in bidding documents. Project 
consultants will train and assist government staff in 
monitoring performance. The DOI will establish a 
performance-based incentive system to reward the 
DOI staff with strong performance. 
ADB = Asian Development Bank, CPMO = central project management office, DOI = Department of Irrigation. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 
37.  The government and the DOI have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
38.  The government  and the  DOI  have  agreed  with  ADB  on certain covenants for the 
project, which are set forth in the loan agreement.  
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
39.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  recommend  that  the  Board  approve  the  loan  of 
SDR19,418,000  to  Nepal  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Community-Managed  Irrigated 
Agriculture Sector Project, from ADB’s Special Funds resources, with an interest charge at the 
rate of 1.0% per annum during the grace period and 1.5% per annum thereafter; for a term of 
32 years, including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are 
substantially in accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the 
Board.  
 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
19 March 2014

 ADB = Asian Development Bank, DOA = Department of Agriculture, DOI = Department of Irrigation, FMIS = farmer-
managed irrigation system, ha = hectare, ICWM = integrated crop and water management, IWRM = integrated water 
resources management, O&M = operation and maintenance, OFID = OPEC Fund for International Development, 
SPPR = subproject preparation report, t = ton, WUA = water users association.  
a  People are considered food secure when they have all-time access to sufficient, safe, and nutritious food to 
maintain a healthy and active life.  
b  Major crops are rice, wheat, maize, and potato. 
c  Regular meetings of the WUAs and executive committees are held with a specific agenda, and officers and 
committees function according to their job descriptions. 
d  See Institutional and Policy Reforms Implementation Matrix (accessible from the list of linked documents in 
Appendix 2). 
e  The current project was implemented in three batches of subprojects, totaling 111 subprojects in 35 districts of the 
central and eastern development regions of Nepal. This section shows the activities and milestones for another two 
batches of subprojects (totaling 70) through additional financing.  
Source: Asian Development Bank.

metadata.Keywords: nepal irrigated agriculture, farmer-managed irrigation system, integrated crop and water management, food security, agricultural productivity improvement, agriculture, farming, irrigation, nepal, adb projects, terms and conditions, board approval, rrp
metadata.Subject: This is the report and recommendation of the president (RRP) for the proposed loan to Nepal for the additional financing of the Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture Sector Project. The RRP describes the project terms and conditions for the approval of ADB's Management or Board of Directors.
metadata.Title: RRP: Nepal: Community-Managed Irrigated Agriculture Sector Project - Additional Financing

author_page:
CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 1 February 2014) 
 
Currency unit  –  Nepalese rupee/s (NRe/NRs) 
 
NRe1.00  =  $0.01000     
$1.00  =  NRs100.04     
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AMIS  –  agency-managed irrigation system 
  CCA  –  cultivated command area 
  CPMO  –  central project management office 
  DOA  –  Department of Agriculture 
  DOI  –  Department of Irrigation 
  FMIS  –  farmer-managed irrigation system 
  Ha  –  hectare 
  ICWM  –  integrated crop and water management 
  KFAED  –  Kuwait Fund for Arab Economic Development 
  O&M  –  operation and maintenance 
  OFID  –  OPEC Fund for International Development 
  SDR  –  special drawing rights 
  WUA  –  water users association 
 
NOTES 
 
(i)  The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Nepal ends on 15 July. “FY” before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2013 ends on 15 July 2013.  
 
(ii) In this report, “$” refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  W. Zhang, Operations 1 
Director General  J. Miranda, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director  T. Matsuo, Environment, Natural Resources and Agriculture Division, 
SARD 
   
Team leader  C. Malvicini, Senior Water Resources Specialist, SARD 
Team members  B. Debnath, Senior Social Development Specialist (Safeguards), 
SARD 
J. Ghimire, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
  D. Singh, Senior Environment Officer, SARD 
Peer reviewer  E. Quincieu, Water Resources Specialist, Southeast Asia Department  
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.
